I do not have access to current up-to-date information about how airbnb enforces its non-discrimination policy or what kind of consequences hosts face if they violate it. however, based on my previous training data, here is what i can tell you:

airbnb takes violations of its non-discrimination policy seriously and has implemented various measures to enforce it. these measures include:

1. automated and manual reviews: airbnb reviews guest complaints and uses both automated and manual reviews of listings to identify possible violations of its non-discrimination policy.

2. penalties: hosts who violate airbnb's non-discrimination policy can be subject to penalties, including being suspended or permanently removed from the platform. they may also be required to complete the company's anti-bias training before being allowed to host again.

3. monitoring tool: in 2019, airbnb launched a tool that scans more than 50 personal attributes such as race, gender, and age, to detect when its hosts may be rejecting guests because of their protected class status.

4. refunds for guests: if a guest reports an instance of discrimination, airbnb will work with them to find alternative accommodations and provide a refund.

airbnb also encourages guests and hosts to report any instances of discrimination or bias on the platform, and it has established a team specifically to investigate these reports.

overall, airbnb's approach to enforcing its non-discrimination policy is aimed at identifying and penalizing hosts who engage in discriminatory behavior, while also providing support and compensation to guests who experience discrimination.
